column3: Soderbergh tries his hand at action thrillers.
column7:
2 out of 7 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
Simultaneously premiering here in the UAE, viewers are going to be spoilt for choice between "Haywire" and "War Horse". ss versus SS. Steven Soderbergh versus Steven Spielberg. David versus Goliath. Opposite Spielberg, Soderbergh may appear to be the underdog, and as we know, everyone loves the underdog. However, this time around I am not so sure.

The plot is fairly simple with covert agent Mallory Kane (Gina Carano) accepting a 'light' job where she must pose as the wife of a British agent, simply known as Paul (Michael Fassbender). Arriving in Dublin, Mallory finds her contact murdered; the same person she helped rescue as a hostage just a week before. Her suspicions of being double crossed and framed are confirmed when she is attacked and nearly killed by Paul. Back in the United States, Mallory contacts agency head Coblenz (Michael Douglas) who suspects her former lover Kenneth (Ewan McGregor) of being a rogue agent. Mallory must now settle the score once and for all and heads toward a showdown in Mexico.

Seen this movie before? Sure you have. Instead of Jason Bourne, we have a female lead. How many times before have we seen a Special Ops agent who gets double crossed, then does a U-turn hell bent on revenge? Uma Thurman in "Kill Bill". Angelina Jolie in "Salt". Zoe Saldana in "Columbiana" and the list goes on. On top of that, there is a lot of praise for Carano doing her own stunts. Why is that so surprising when middle-aged Tom Cruise did his own stunts outside the world's tallest building? Then again, the difference between Carano and someone like Thurman or Saldana is that the latter two are actors, whereas Carano is a former MMA fighter whose idea of acting has a lot of 'my-foot-in-your-face' attitude.

I am not saying that this movie is a waste of time. All I'm saying is that coming from someone like Soderbergh, you would expect an edge-of-your-seat movie experience. Like "Contagion" and the "Oceans" franchise before, you can expect Soderbergh's hallmark plethora of A-listers in supporting roles. Having said that, shouldn't the leading actor be as good or better than the supporting cast? Carano does try, and I think she will make an excellent action movie star, but she needs the necessary exposure as a serious actor to match her skilled abilities in martial arts. If not, I'm afraid Carano could be treading the same path as martial artist and B-movie actress Cynthia Rothrock. The remaining stars perform as expected with some good antagonism from Fassbender and McGregor. Channing Tatum, Michael Douglas and Antonio Banderas are in their own comfort zones without having to do much.

For an action movie, pacing is not too bad with some equally good fight choreography. Soderbergh could be testing uncharted waters here as this is his first movie with some brutal fight scenes. One particular scene has Mallory punched, kicked and thrown around like a stuffed toy owned by an evil little brat. Evidently, Soderbergh got it right with the fight scenes, because most other action scenes appears to be cut-copy-pasted, and comes with some of the clichés you would expect in a high end Hollywood action caper.

All in all, this is an average action thriller, but nothing we haven't seen before and definitely nothing to write home about.

Steven Soderbergh is responsible for some great films, known for their back and forth time lines. I found the Oceans three to be a breath of fresh air in the movie industry giving new meaning to the 'smash and grab'.

Unlike the Angelina Jolie's of this world she looked like she actually ate food as opposed to sniffing it, which as a woman who is bombarded with images of what we should look like all the time, was lovely.

From there however I do believe this film is not as great as it could have been. The bad guys were not bad enough, the fight scenes showed very little blood (I am not a gore hound however it just wasn't believable) and I must say it was not easy to follow as it just didn't seem to flow.

Not a waste of money but not great either.

With Steven Soderbergh at helm for this movie, and a cast including renowned thespians Ewan McGregor, Michael Douglas, Micheal Fassbender and Antonio Banderas, one could have expected much, much more.

No doubt, there were some good action sequences throughout the movie but most of the scenes (including the chase and creeping-behind-people- stupidly-and-trying-to-kill-them scenes) were just too moronic and needless to be watched even for the average movie-goer.

Her screen presence is somewhat distracting as she only mutters a few one-liners and kill guys with moves that I would deem awkward.

Overall, it was like a minimalist approach to making a action movie that didn't work at all. Now if you would excuse me, I need to delete all the memory of this movie in my mind.

column9: If you expected "Haywire" to be a cheesy action film designed to capitalize on Gina Carano in provocative outfits you'd be disappointed. Academy Award winner Steven Soderbergh is far too good a director for that and what we have here is a well crafted vehicle for Carano to display her martial arts expertise. When she's not dispatching foes as an agent for an unscrupulous private contractor, her character Mallory Kane, maintains a wary attitude towards strangers. The only person she trusts is her father, an author of war novels, played by Bill Paxton. The plot may be standard deja vu action genre stuff but "Haywire" can boast a far better cast than you typically see. Michael Douglas is a government agent who wants Mallory to help him uncover a traitor in the organization. Ewan McGregor and Channing Tatum are Mallory's boss and former partner respectively. Michael Fassbender is an agent who Mallory thinks has been brought in to work on a mission with her. Antonio Banderas is a shadowy operative working with the government. "Haywire" looks and feels like an Indie film. It's structured like a standard Hollywood actioner but it wants to possess an authenticity a big Hollywood production would find too restrictive. Gina Carano obviously doesn't have a lot of acting chops yet so don't go expecting Angelina Jolie in "Salt". Overall I found it an entertaining hour and a half.

column9:
Haywire (2011)

** (out of 4)

Gina Carano plays a black ops soldier who is double crossed by her agency so she sets out to find out who sold her out and why. HAYWIRE got released to very little noise but on its opening weekend things heated up as people left the theater extremely unhappy with what they watched. I've never really understood these "CinemaScore" groups as they always appear to give films low ratings if the films don't deliver on their expectations. Director Steven Soderbergh clearly wanted to do an experimental action movie and I will admit that this is unlike any other action movie out there. With that said, while I can appreciate Soderbergh wanted to try something new and experimental, that doesn't mean it was a success. I think there are some interesting ideas floating around in this film but in the end I just found it to be rather dull, lifeless and without a bit of energy. The movie seems to want to be something that Jean-Luc Godard would direct had he been given an action script. The movie features very bizarre camera angles, strange fight sequences and a really, really strange music score that seems to deliver the same notes no matter what type of emotion a scene is meant to have. These strange directorial changes make for a unique and original experience but it really does seem as Soderbergh went overboard on the style while not delivering any substance. The biggest problem is that the story is so one-note that it's really hard to care about the lead or worry about who set her up. Another problem is that all of the all-star cast members are pretty much wasted in thankless roles. Names like Michael Douglas, Antonio Banderas, Channing Tatum, Bill Paxton and Michael Fassbender signed onto the picture and I'm guessing mainly as a favor to the director. This was my first time seeing Carano in anything. She doesn't give a "good" performance but she can act the part as the tough action hero just fine. HAYWIRE, without any doubt, is an experiment that had a few good ideas but in the end they just never added up to anything.

column9:
Soderbergh's take on the 'Bourne genre'; it's simple as that. However, I must say, this movie seems like it does not know what it wants to be.

Even as a big fan of Steven Soderbergh, Haywire comes across to me as an unsatisfactory piece. I think the main problem is that the characters- all of them- are not interesting enough to care for. I hate to say it, but Malory Cane is one of the blandest protagonists I've ever seen recently- especially in the area of the 'Bourne genre'.

That's not to say that there was anything wrong with Gina Carano's performance. She gives an appropriate amount of weight to the character, as well as to the over-all atmosphere and tone. So I say Malory Cane is just a badly written character.

Speaking of characters, it feels like the element of huge ensemble of cast has become sort of a trademark for Steven Soderbergh movies. However, I honestly never saw it as a flaw until this film.

Even in the Ocean's series where there are, always, at least eleven main characters(which is a nightmare for writers/directors to develop and portray properly), all of the characters had unique, genuine, and interesting aspects, as the mix with big number of big actors always turned out as great synergy effect.

In fact, the 'huge cast' element even worked fantastically in last year's "Contagion (2011)", even when that film was a "story with out a drama" type of movie. It was great. I loved it.

However, Haywire suffers as the all big actors fail to cover the lack of 'live characters interacting' with each other, to the point where:

Soderbergh-style cinematography, some actually very impressive fight choreography, delicate touch in staging the actors with making seemingly ordinary locations look beautiful, intelligent dry humor,

...all fail to cover-up for the lack of density the film has to offer.

the actors were- surprisingly- not utilized very well, the characters were forgettable, there was very little suspense throughout the movie, it wasn't funny, it wasn't serious,

and it just wasn't entertaining enough.

For people who are not familiar with Steven Soderbergh movies, it's a slow-paced action movie that's shot beautifully... but that's about it.

Oh, also, I think for this one instance, David Holmes' music did not work for the movie. That doesn't help much either.

column9:
I had to write a review here, because of the many 0 and 1 reviews that were just unfair, to the point where I wonder if some of those people are brainwashed. First, to all the people saying the fights didn't look real : are you kidding me ? They were way above most fights on any actions movies out there, it sounds like you people are so much used to unreal Hollywood choreographed fights that it became the standard for reality in your minds. Those fights were raw, violent and efficient. Nothing stylish in it, she is not dancing, she is protecting herself with real moves. And this is one of the few positive points of this movie.

Secondly, she sure has to improve her acting skills, but come on people, she still acts better than Kirsten Stewarts and yet the later one is considered as an actress, when miss Carano is just starting her carrier. She is quite good looking, she actually looks like a normal person, not an anorexic Hollywood freak and she definitely fits her character. I'd definitely like to see her in movies with a good, real scenario.

Regarding the film itself, well, the scenario is weak as well as the dialogs. Revealing the intrigue at the end doesn't work, because, and I agree here with what other people say, it is hard to follow the story as there isn't any until the end. It does feel like random scenes following each other with no apparent reason. But blame Soderbergh, not the actors. Overall, I'd give this movie a 5, for the fights, the familiar faces (McGregor, Douglas...) and miss Carano who has potential, and should be given a chance. But I gave an 8 to compensate all those foolish comments about realism in fights and Carano's acting skills.

column3: Good film, if you don't take it too seriously
column7:
2 out of 9 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9: Every time I watch a movie I go to IMDb and look it up to see what others think. I was surprised at all the 1 stars people gave for this film. People complained about the acting, directing, plot, even the music! And yet I doubt most if any could act any better, write scripts any better, or really know a thing about directing a film. All right it wasn't the best Oscar winning epic, but neither was it the worst by far. I have sat through/fallen asleep during many other films that are far worse than Haywire. You should see it for what it is, 90 minutes of fun where you get to see a good looking girl kick some ass, and you shouldn't take it too seriously. If you want to see some mindless movie where there are explosions and death every ten seconds, then see something else. The film was a snapshot, a sequence of events that had no real beginning or conclusion - it left that up to the imagination of the viewer. It is so easy to be an armchair critic, anyone can do it. But to act, write and direct takes courage and to all those who love to pull people down, I say get up there and see if you can do any better, and we'll all have a laugh. This is coming from someone who's a drama graduate and has done acting, writing and directing, and it ain't easy. This film was good and I would recommend it to anyone who like the action/thriller genre.

column9:
For the size of a film filled with Hollywood's top stars, I must admit this film is disappointing. The dialogue is flat and boring, and lack of recognition of roles and characters makes the audience do not get the depth of this film. I almost fell asleep in every dialogue scene.

Gina Carano can do martial art, but she obviously can not act. I can not understand why the producers and director chose her as the lead role. There are many actresses who can do action scenes but can still make a convincing acting (milla jovovich or kate beckinsale just to show a few).

In terms of film technique, the lighting is very poor. many indoor scenes looked dim and unattractive because of the lack of variations in lighting. whether the lighting department was lazy to set the lights or it was deliberately made that way. even a dark movie like underworld trilogy can show a perfect lighting technique.

cinematography also looks like an amateur. looked like there was only one camera used throughout the film. It rarely moves, no multiple angle shot and stays with the same position. For an action movie, it makes the movie boring and less bite. There are also many scenes which I think should have been cut, but still continued without any dialog that make the actors/actres looked confused to improvise.

Of all the actors in this film, i think only michael douglas showed his class even though not much scenes with him.

I really do not understand what Steven Soderbergh was thinking. He didn't look like serious doing this film. I mean, look at Erin Brokovich, Traffic, Ocean's trilogy... Haywire definitely looks like a failed experiment.

column3: The problem with female action stars.
column7:
2 out of 9 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9: Haywire is far better than your average action movie. So why the disappointing box office turnout? This may seem like a disgustingly simple explanation but here goes anyway. Who is this film for? Die hard action film fans? That's MEN by the way. Of course it is! Right? It stars Gina Carrano - MMA Goddess! Carrano is backed by an all-star cast to boot. If it were true that a movie with a female action star was that appealing to male action movie fans then the $$$ would reflect that. But it doesn't. So does this appeal to women? Women want to see a strong attractive woman be a hero and save the day don't they? Well... no they don't. There's a reason chick flicks are generally devoid of martial arts and explosions. So is "Haywire" a date movie? No. I'm sorry if that sounds sexist but who wants to have that awkward "you thought she was prettier than me" conversation? Yeah that's right somebody's gotta say it. It's a gender issue. Sure there have been plenty of successful action movies with female leads but this is different in that Carrano's toughness is masculine toughness and we're not ready to be sold that. Maybe if woman's MMA really catches on this will start to change. It'll certainly have to make it to the UFC first. At its best this film could be the first step toward deconstructing gender roles in a new way.

column9:
Being an avid MMA fan when I got word that Gina Carano would be transitioning to acting, Haywire was definitely on my checklist. For her first film it went surprisingly well. A plot that although starts off very sketchy in detail slowly unravels itself in 15 minute intervals. In many ways it wasn't too fictional of a role considering the fact that this is a former champion. Think about it, a beautiful woman who kicks the crap out of various people for a fat paycheck. Not too shabby.

There's pretty descent action scenes as Tatum gets arm barred, Fassbender goes to sleep in a triangle joke and a random cop gets superman punched. All the correct elements were in place to make this an enjoyable 90 minutes; great supporting cast accompanied by a smooth soundtrack. Only thing i disliked was how half of the film's premise takes place via a conversation in a car as flashbacks of prior events are shown; but in hindsight that's neither here or there.

Want to see a hot chick cripple some fools in a mystery thriller? If nothing but out of curiosity, you should check this out.

column9:
I loved this movie... I wasn't expecting much because of all the mixed reviews, but I was pleasantly surprised.

One thing to note is that the movie was shot in a kind of 70's style. This may turn people off because you don't see the over the top "gloss" that is associated with your typical Hollywood action movie. So it may come across as low budget, with odd music choices. However about halfway through I figured out that this is actually a throwback to some of the old 70's action/suspense/crime/spy films. The movie style, dialog, etc. A young Michael Caine or Sean Connery would fit right in here.

If you don't pick that up or appreciate this "retro" style, you're not going to like it. If you do then you're in for a treat and beautiful cinematography.

The action and choreography was fantastic... Not for being crazy and over the top, but for being INCREDIBLY realistic . This isn't your typical "suspend your belief for a moment while a skinny Barbie chick throws a 300 pound man across the room with her finger". No this looked and felt *real*... It wasn't until after the movie that I learned that the main actress was a former mixed martial arts fighter. I never got the sense that she was fighting beyond that of a real highly trained woman. This made me sympathize with the character much more.

The plot is simple and straightforward, but reveals a complex relationship between the characters.

If you're looking your typical over the top Hollywood action flick starring Lucy Liu, Bruce Willis, and featuring big explosions and high tech spy gear then skip it... You're not going to like it. If you're looking for an atypical action movie that's subtle in it's delivery and a true throwback to some of the pure, gritty and straight forward movies from the 70's then you won't be disappointed.

I'd LOVE to see a sequel or even a television series, but I doubt that will ever happen because people really didn't know what to make of this movie... Some people were expecting an action movie and got a "film", others were expecting great drama with hi profile actors, but instead got an action movie.

In reality Haywire is part action movie and part "film". This makes it very unique and rather odd at the same time. Action movies typically break ground through more special effects, however Haywire does the opposite by going "retro".

So if you are of those two minds you will love this movie. Otherwise you will just see it as falling short in either category.

column9:
I watched this last night and wondered who was playing the lead female role in this movie, I had never seen her before. So I googled it and came up with the name, Gina Carano. Still none the wiser I did a little more research and found out she is an ex pro-cage fighter and was on the TV show, American Gladiator. Ah, now I understand why she cannot act to save her life!

What on earth were a bunch of otherwise respected and talented people thinking when they cast her in this? She only has 2 facial expressions, one is a kind of smug smirk and the other is a completely blank 1000 yard stare.

The film is basically a waste of time, its a big budget all star vehicle for and actress who cannot act. But can she fight? Well, maybe she can, I have not seen any of here "real life" bouts but on the showing of this film she can't fight either. Perhaps that is not her fault, the fight scenes are so preposterously overplayed and unrealistic its difficult to take them seriously. They are brutal, for sure, but realistic, never. I don't care how tough you are but if you take several full on punches to the face from a big guy you are not going to get up in a hurry let alone get up without a scratch on you!!

So what is the movie supposed to be? The plot is thin, very thin indeed so we can't class it as a serious spy movie like "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy". Its not a glossy all action CGI action fest like the Mission Impossible franchise either. Its doesn't have the glamour and charm of a Bond tittle and neither does it have the gritty realism of the Bourne movies, though I suspect this is what they were aiming at more than anything else. Its simply a case of badly wasted talent. The only up side to the whole experience was that it was mercifully short.

But there is one ray of light at the end of the tunnel. Judging from the poor ratings it is receiving I doubt there will be a sequel.

column7:
1 out of 3 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
Haywire was a much different movie than I was expecting. In a good way. Not to say there aren't weaknesses: the plot is contrived and the elevator-like music during the otherwise thrilling action sequences is absurd. Those give way to the tension in the chases followed by the brutal hand to hand combat sequences. Newcomer and retired MMA fighter Gina Carano more than holds her own in a cast littered with talent. She gets to kick some all star ass in a very convincing manner. The way she throws punches and kicks is different than the way a typical actor would. There are cool moves here and there, yet, it's not at all stylized.

The movie centers on Mallory Kane, a contract black ops agent who suddenly finds herself hunted by everyone she comes across – seemingly like all thrillers of this sort. Unlike others in this genre, Mallory hasn't seemingly done anything to deserve this. We're never led to believe she knows too much or was too nosy. Many reviewers have called this an inferior version of the Bourne movies. I think it's better than all but the original Bourne, largely thanks to A-list director Steven Soderbergh. The comparisons beyond that are moot.

In many ways Haywire is a nonstop action film. There's terrific tension at all times because we know right from the beginning that Mallory is being hunted. There's nothing new about the "show me the middle of the movie first" structure, but it's hardly this well utilized. From her first uneasy meeting with Aaron (Channing Tatum in his best acting turn yet), we're in her shoes. We don't trust anyone. There is a particular long chase scene where Mallory is simply trying to get away from the scene by walking down the street. Her glances spot her tail across the way. She doesn't just start running. She continues walking and waits until she turns a corner and has the upper hand to break into a sprint. She's also not dumb enough to look back until she thinks she's in the clear.

That's what seems to separate Mallory and the rest of Haywire from lesser action thrillers. Mallory is smart. She knows when to snoop. She knows when to walk. She knows when she's in over her head and is more than willing to run instead of fight. Perhaps this is her first separation from her male protagonists that typically dominate the genre. She's patient, calculating. Is she a bad ass capable of taking out two swat officers at the same time? Sure, but she'll wait until she really has the advantage to do it.

In terms of more raw action, there are a few one-on-one fights with men where we never question if she can hold her own. None of the fights are the same. She faces adversaries that are either young and athletic, polished and professional, or more comfortable behind a desk. Thank God for once the desk job guy doesn't have some secret fighting ability that he's been hiding the entire time for some reason. Her friends and foes are played by the likes of Channing Tatum, Michael Douglas, Antonio Banderas, Ewan McGregor, and Michael Fassbender. That's as well rounded a cast as you'll ever see in a movie like this.

The not-so-subtle name Mallory has an etymology meaning "bad," which is ironic as Mallory isn't a contract killer. She carries out jobs requiring a high level of military skill. She believes the work she is doing is good. The first job we follow her on is a hostage rescue. The next is to be eye candy with an MI6 agent. Of course, neither turns out to be as it seems at first, but that's what they are in her eyes.

For more reviews like this one as well as other movie musings, go to http://thethreeacts.wordpress.com/

column9:
Gina can't act. No facial expressions. No variances in tone for delivery of lines. No charisma! There were a lot of cut-aways from her face. Voice-overs instead. Like when she's on the phone, or talking to another character, they show the other character, not her, but you hear her voice. Or times her face would be in shadowy darkness, or her back was shown when she was talking. Or scenes were shot at a distance. I can only assume the filmmakers notice the same as me, no facial expressions whatsoever and decided to shoot it this way.

I love love love badass kickass women on screen. Some of my favourites are Kate Beckinsale in the Underworld movies, Angelina Jolie in the Tomb Raider movies and Salt, Linda Hamilton in T2, Sigourney Weaver in Aliens, Milla Jovovich in the Resident Evil movies, Peta Wilson in the Nikita series, and Lucy Lawless in Xena. All these women can convey anger, grief, surprise, softness, humour, steely-eyed coolness, and so much more using facial expressions, body language, and the right vocal tone for delivery of lines. That's what makes a great female action star. Not just fighting skills.

Was the idea to cast a bunch of talented stars in this, and therefore it will be hit? I mean Michael Fassbender, Ewan McGregor, Bill Paxton, Antonio Banderas, Michael Douglas! The look-at-the-talented- actors stunt didn't work. From what I can tell the movie didn't generate much at the box office. Not a whopping hit! The "a-listers" here seemed awkward and out of place, and most definitely wasn't any of the actors' best work. I won't include Channing Tatum. He and his wooden acting fit in perfectly.

The story was ho-hum recycled from Salt, the Bourne films and others. Normally recycling stories wouldn't bother me, and I'd be OK with that if it were well done, but it wasn't. Add to that, the bad acting, an annoying soft black fish-eye effect, and dullness of it all, made it, well frankly, yawn zzzzzzzz....

Has a pretty cool sound track. A lot of sound track actually. Because there aren't much lines. None of the actors had much to say. What does that tell you?

I honestly wanted to like this. I was so looking forward to another great female kickass action movie and heroine and possibly a continuing series. To my disappointment, this is what I got instead, dull story and bad acting! 4/10

column9:
I really don't understand all of the snarky, hate filled reviews of this movie. Apparently the 14 year old boys who have written the cookie cutter bad reviews don't like the lack of cgi or nudity. The action in this film is much more realistic than the usual fantastical, beyond human capability, action, and the car chase is real world, not impossible cgi enhanced.

As for the acting, well Gina Carano isn't going to sway any academy voters, but she is fine in the role of a double-crossed government contractor, and is a worthy stunt performer. Ewan McGregor, Channing Tatum, and Michael Fassbender are believable, and Michael Douglas and Antonio Banderas have small contributing parts.

So don't be swayed by the 1 or 2 star teenage boy reviews. This is a satisfying, intelligently scripted film. And Steven Soderberg's usual visual creativity makes this a stylish thriller.

column9:
The problems with HAYWIRE can be laid firmly at the door of director Steven Soderbergh, who is entirely unsuited to directing what should be a pulse-pounding thriller. Soderbergh's light 'n' breezy, art-house-style direction is at odds with the kind of gritty, realistic, down 'n' dirty vibes he's aiming for here, and the result is an oddly unrewarding movie that goes through the motions, ticks all of the boxes, and yet fails to make any impact on the viewer whatsoever. Although it looks good, it turns out to be a hollow, slightly soulless exercise in movie-making.

The good thing about HAYWIRE are the martial arts scenes: they're very well filmed, highly exciting and utilise to full advantage the skills of real-life mixed martial arts fighter and lead Gina Carano. Having recently rewatched the BOURNE trilogy (in preparation for the upcoming BOURNE LEGACY), I can acknowledge they're the equal of anything in those movies. However, it's the long, slow passages in-between the action that really cause this film to stall. Soderbergh shoots them in his usual way, with jazzy music playing in the background and subdued, quick-fire dialogue, and while that worked in the likes of THE LIMEY and OCEAN'S ELEVEN, it just doesn't here.

The whole exercise feels artificial, and you get the impression that Soderbergh is trying too hard. There's no palpable tension, no sense of build-up, no suspense about what's going to happen to the protagonist. In fact, it's all rather boring, and you're left itching for the next fight scene to take place. Compare this with THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, in which I was on the edge of my seat during the non-action bits, caught up in an involved conspiracy storyline, unable to wait to find out what was going to happen next. HAYWIRE flatlines between the martial arts antics.

The script doesn't help; it's on the level of the average Seagal DTV actioner, and makes some truly odd decisions (like highly skilled/unbeatable agent Carano telling her life story in flashback to a random stranger throughout the course of the film – far better to have adopted a linear structure and just begun at the beginning instead of this wannabe clever-clever stuff). There are other pluses: the cast is faultless, and Soderbergh even elicits a rather effective performance from walking muscle Channing Tatum. But some of the seasoned performers are underutilised: Douglas, Banderas and Paxton are given little to work with, and Ewan McGregor is miscast in a wishy-washy role.

column9:
The classic "secret agent betrayed by the government" plot is one of the most popular ones in straight-to-DVD cinema, in which we have many times seen "actors" such as Steven Seagal, Dolph Lundgren and Casper Van Dien in cheap action films, fighting against generic villains and provoking all the destruction permitted by the low budget from the project. Under the direction from the acclaimed Steven Soderbergh, the film Haywire took a similar premise to the big screen, with various famous actors, exotic locations and a visual style much more elegant and elaborated than the one we have seen in the previously mentioned straight-to-DVD cinema.

The plot from Haywire is simple, but screenwriter Lem Dobbs complicated it by telling it through flashbacks, and as a consequence, the screenplay takes shape gradually, creating suspense and occasionally surprising us when the connection between apparently isolated events is revealed. I also liked the way in which Dobbs outlined the story in broad strokes so that we take care of filling in the details, basing ourselves on the ambiguous dialogs and other clues left by the screenplay. I also liked the visual style, simultaneously retro and modern, but with an own identity which doesn't feel as an aesthetic ornament, but as a valid technique which complements the dynamic narrative.

Gina Carano achieved fame in the Mixed Martial Arts sport, and she also participated in some TV roles. Haywire is her debut as a film actress, and I'm glad to say that her work is extraordinary. She displays a magnetic presence, overflowing charisma and an intensity we will never see in "action actresses" who obviously need stunt doubles even to open the door of a car (Jessica Alba and Katherine Heigl come to mind). In supporting roles, we find Michael Douglas, Antonio Banderas, Bill Paxton, Channing Tatum and Michael Fassbender playing characters which are a bit hollowly written, and which represent gear in order to facilitate the screenplay's advance. The only actor who plays a well built supporting role is Ewan McGregor, and he makes a solid work.

In conclusion, I recommend Haywire. Despite a few forced details from the story and the previously mentioned hollow supporting characters, I liked it pretty much, because of its interesting screenplay, Carano's brilliant work, and Soderbergh's creative direction.

column9:
After reading mixed reviews on Haywire I wasn't expecting much and in doing so I actually enjoyed this. If you go into this film expecting a Jason Statham, Bond or Bourne movie though you will be disappointed.

Haywire is not your average action movie, whilst the formula is still the same (double crossed agent seeks revenge) it's the delivery that is different. If you had to put this movie in a certain category it would be 'Arthouse'.

If it wasn't for the big cast I doubt this movie would have seen the light of day. The main character Gina Corano has an enormous presence on screen and I predict big things for her in the future. Unfortunately Ewan McGregor's part is pretty lame, Michael Fassbender Mi6 agent is very convincing, Banderas and Douglas also make this film more watchable.

column9:
The Hollywood Machine again disappoints. What was the deal with Haywire. Throw a bunch of names in a movie for a couple of scenes each and put up an action trailer and except to clean up. A handful of star names spit out crap dialogue as the plot tries to cover up a fighter that fights well and sounds like robo cop when she speaks. I read after on line that they altered her voice. Why? Her delivery was robotic as it was, why the Robocop touch, maybe if they made her an actual robot it would have paid off, but she wasn't a robot, she was an ex op who should be able to crush her opponents – which she did, look good doing it – which she did, and deliver her lines dramatically and efficiently – which she didn't. In addition to struggling through her lines, she ran around awkwardly and continuously during a couple of scenes with odd background music. I have to admit, the score was daring, but it didn't fit the movie. It might have been better than the movie, because it was daring and creative and not the typical you'd find in an action movie, but it didn't match up at times. You can't throw ranch dressing on a pile of crap and expect miracles. In the end, even though the music was interesting, it didn't work in the movie, it stood out too much, and when u start to notice the music a lot more than the movie that's a problem. There are too many problems with this movie and not enough substance.

column9:
Soderbergh turns his hand to the 'Action' genre, with mixed success. Casting M.M.A. fighter Carano in the lead gives the fight scenes a realistic edge; on the flip side it is obvious that she's not a natural actress. Her delivery of dialogue is at best mechanical. Thankfully the role doesn't involve too much speaking. Probably Soderbergh's reputation helped secure some heavyweight names to play other characters including a suave Michael Douglas (in what I think is his first post cancer-battle role) and dependable Ewan McGregor. The movie's plot revolves around private contract agent Kane (Carano) being betrayed by her employer - yeah, that old chestnut. We see a lot of the narrative through flashback scenes as the betrayal unfolds. Keeping up with the twists takes some concentration and I felt the story was a overly convoluted at times. Since the 'Bourne' films all action/espionage productions that want to be taken seriously apparently feel it is necessary to cram in as much shadow play as possible. 'Haywire' does have it's good moments, that revolve around the hand to hand combat. But like a jaded diamond, it lacks sparkle.

column9:
In the annals of cinema history, there should now be a term or definition for a poorly written and filmed movie. That definition should be "Haywire". You may be asking, "what does he mean by definition?". I mean to say that after experiencing and watching a bad film, when someone asks "what was that film you just saw like?". You aptly respond, "It was a 'Haywire' film". "A Haywire film?". "Yes, the film I just saw was poorly written, filmed and featured some serious overacting, like that film 'Haywire'."

There was only one cinematic positive to come out of Haywire. Antonio Banderas, Michael Douglas, Ewan Mcgregor, and Michael Fassbender are all now unquestionably confirmed as the talented and skillful performers they are seen to be. This is because despite the fact that they were reciting lines from a poorly written script, they unsurprisingly performed their depth- lacking roles convincingly to a confused and disinterested audience.

column9:
"You shouldn't think of her as being a woman. That would be a mistake." After freeing a Chinese journalist that is being held hostage black-ops government agent Mallory (Carano) is double-crossed. She has now become a target of highly skilled assassins who are sent to get rid of her. She must use all of her skills to fight her way through them and discover who was behind the double-cross. I was looking forward to this one based on the exciting preview. The movie started off good enough but very quickly began to drag and made me lose interest throughout. Some of the dialog is laughable and the music cues consisted of a 5 measure sequence ripped off from "Ocean's 11". At first it was neat but began to get annoying. Even though Carano is an MMA fighter in real life the fight sequences looked very choreographed and for an action movie it wasn't really all that exciting. All that said though if you liked "Salt" or "Columbiana" you will most likely like this one too. Not terrible but not original at all. Overall, a movie that is best described as Salt 6 - after "Hanna", "Columbiana", "Cat Run", etc...I give it a B-.

column9:
On paper, Steven Soderbergh's first foray into action-movie territory is certainly too good to give this a miss -- HAYWIRE stars former MMA fighter-turned-actress Gina Carano (who was best known in TV's reality show called American Gladiators) and favors clean-cut fight choreography unlike most like-minded movies (read: shaky-cam) shown these days. Unfortunately, what you have read or seen in the promotional materials that have been heavily advertised all this while, isn't exactly the kind of straightforward action-packed extravaganza you would hope for. Instead HAYWIRE is an artistic farce disguised as a B-grade action wannabe and worst of all, it's unbelievably boring.

Full review at http://caseymoviemania.blogspot.com/2012/03/haywire-2012.html

column9:
Movie Review: "Haywire" – Being a huge Steven Soderbergh fan, I was shocked by the crap that I had just witnessed up on the screen. And that's to put it nicely!!! What a waste of talent, time, money. OMG!!!!! The plot of this film is so terribly predictable, the dialogue is pathetic, the action sequences are boring, and Channing Tatum CAN NOT ACT, do I need to go on???? Basically this is Soderbergh's attempt at the espionage genre, and it fails MISERABLY!!!!!! In a nutshell, a black ops team is sent into Barcelona to save a kidnapped victim; only to be betrayed by the organization that hired them (sound familiar. Yeah, it's that film "insert title here"). Anyways, new comer Gina Carano plays Mallory Kane a freelance covert operative. Hire by Ewan McGregor (Kenneth), her handler and (maybe) lover. not certain, to be part of the Barcelona assault team; and later recruited recruits her to assist the British MI6 team. However, Mallory, who is always suspicious, quickly suspects something is peculiar; and once the attempt on her life is repelled IT'S TIME FOR REVENGE!! I only really enjoyed two (2) scenes in this film. The first being the opening sequence in which Channing Tatum (Aaron) gets his ass handed to him by Mallory; and second the fight sequence between Mallory and the British agent (Michael Fassbender). Everything else the film has to offer has been done, time and time again. And way better! Not an awful film, just not up to the standard that you have could to expect in a Steven Soderbergh film. (BTW, though not a pivotal role, but Michael Douglas (Coblenz) looks fantastic in this film glad to see that's he back on the big screen after and recovering well after his stint with cancer). column9:
The main problem with HAYWIRE is that the script is severely underwritten. Not just in the usual sense of depth and character, but more importantly in the sense that it plays like an unfinished script. Sort of like the screenwriter ran out of time finishing a draft and someone said, "Look, just slap a closing scene on it and the intern will start making copies." It really feels that incomplete. So in the end you feel cheated.

All of this is a shame because HAYWIRE had the potential to be a pretty solid action movie. The cast, as usual for Soderbergh, is A-list. The locations, sets, action, all fine. And that brings us to Gina Carano, whom I was expecting to be the weakest link in the film. Well, far from it. Sure, she's got a long way to go before she'll be cast in an Alexander Payne film, but in this film she's perfect. And to Soderbergh's credit, there are some stunning action sequences that probably work better because of a lack of "acting." One moment in particular is a shot of Carano leaving a hotel knowing she is being followed. The camera stays in front of her as she walks briskly at us. No music, no running, just fast walking and the natural sounds of the street. You would never see that in a Bourne or 007 film. But I thought the effect was wonderful and provided a brittle tension that finally exploded into an excellent chase sequence.

Unfortunately, moments like those are all for naught since the script is simply MIA. And if Steven Soderbergh can miss such basic story structure problems like the ones in HAYWIRE, then maybe a few years painting might do him some good.

column9: There is no doubt that Soderbergh is one of the most commercially viable independent filmmakers working today. Consistently inventive with his directing techniques and constantly challenging himself with various genres. It's unfortunate that his gracious effort in the action genre succumbs to "over direction". An operative is sent to Barcelona to retrieve an asset, however she soon discovers that it's all a setup and must investigate who the culprit is. There are certain elements that really work, and many that send this conspiracy thriller tumbling down the route of genericism. The action, although infrequent, was shot with precision. It allowed Carano, a well established MMA fighter, to perform her own stunts cleanly. A refreshing change from the "shaky cam" method and rapid quick cuts. The ensemble cast all performed well, sure there were several moments of monotony, however it's a cold calculated environment. Soderbergh maintains a professional aesthetic, both in characters and production, that enhances the nature of the conspiracy. Plenty of varying locations, many kidney punches and a plethora of headlocks. Job done. The problem is that Soderbergh's direction is so outstanding that it acts as a veil for a dull, formulaic and thinly written plot. What should've been an engaging story with decent camera techniques has now become a case of style over substance, and it just doesn't work. Simply put, it is boring. I don't care for these characters. I don't care for the conspiracy plot. I don't care for the film. It is so focused on introducing famous actors as potential culprits that anything engaging is subsided. The dialogue lacks personality, but I get it. It's a concise thriller. Our protagonist obtains the information she requires and moves on. Rinse and repeat until she has gone through everyone. Haywire was a missed opportunity. Despite the fantastic choreography, direction and cast, you just can't utilise independent contemporary techniques to convey a simple plot. Otherwise, you lose the story which should always come first.

column9:
Haywire has Gina Carrano who is a private contracting secret agent who has a confrontation with colleague Channing Tatum at a diner which gets ugly when he tries to force her to go with him. A kid played by Michael gallantly intervenes and saves her. But he hardly realizes what he's gotten himself into.

Turns out Carrano had just gotten home from missions in Barcelona and Dublin and it was in the latter she was set up for a murder. The only question is which of her colleagues betrayed her. As it turns out she was planning to leave the agency and someone thought she was expendable. Some retirement plan.

Half the film is in flashback as Carrano tells her tale to her new ally Angerano and the other half trying to identify her betrayer.

I wasn't terribly impressed with the film overall though it does have some moments. Things get a bit incoherent at times with the story. I did however love her final confrontation scene with her betrayer and how said betrayer meets his demise.

Michael Douglas and Antonio Banderas are in this and have the look of men happy their paychecks cleared.

Not the best spy thriller out there.

column9:
Private contract covert ops Mallory Kane (debuting MMA fighter Gina Carano) gets entangled into a web of deceit by her employers in a murderous game, where the strongest survive. In search of the genesis of the intrigue, she must withstand the full force of her former colleagues coupled with misinformed police from both Ireland and the US.

The super-cast featuring Antonio Banderas, Channing Tatum, Michael Fassbender, Evan McGregor and Michael Douglas takes a back-seat in this misguided ride, while screen-time gs henerously gifted to Gina Carano, a physical strong woman with considerable sex appeal, but lacking screen presence to carry a movie. Nonetheless the failure of the movie can not be laid on the beginners shoulders, as in general the movie feels inept, lackadaisical and something more expecting of a beginner, not the seasoned helmer Steven Soderbergh. Absolute travesty for someone of such experience giving the title a very apt double meaning regarding the quality of the finished product.

Some have attempted to defend the movie due to the unusual storytelling employed by Soderbergh and breaking traditional camera angles, but essentially there is no redemption, as the story fails to be the backbone, instead we get a styleless insubstantial cacophony of scenes which struggle to deliver a coherent end result.

Framed within a jumpy script (action fast-forwarding from Dublin to New York with a forced shortcut) with little appeal (going through the tired motions of most genre movies) it squeaks and screeches, rarely getting into second gear. The only redeeming sequence is the Dublin hotel fight between our heroine and Fassbender accompanied with the ensuing rooftop chase across the city.

column9:
STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday Morning

After a mission in Barcelona doesn't go to plan, Agent Mallory Kane (Gina Carono) keeps a low profile for a while, until she is once again approached by her superior Kenneth (Ewan McGregor) to travel to Ireland, to pose with another agent (Michael Fassbender) as a couple at an exclusive retreat, in order to snare a French national who's been up to no good. But when Kane finds herself double crossed, she finds herself on the run, framed for a murder she committed in self defense and unable to trust anyone.

The novelty of having a bona fide martial artist in the lead role isn't as strong as it was in the halycon years of Seagal and Van Damme, being in the age of wire fu and CGI and such. So female MA sensation Gina Carano will probably find herself diving nose first towards the straight to DVD path now. As indeed this none event little offering really should have, had it not been for the inexplicable all star cast, a range of old and younger hot talent, and even more inexplicable big name director. One might only assume Steven Soderbergh has some Nicolas Cage style weird leaning towards B action movies, because it's either that or he's really allowed his standards to fall.

An incoherent, convoluted story is matched by a long interval of deadly dull nothingness, as the movie goes through the motions, throwing up all the usual genre clichés, from the characters to the scenarios, with a big name cast carrying it all through, but with all the passion and sincerity of a dead fish. From relative new comers McGregor and Fassbender, to old hands like Antonio Banderas and Michael Douglas in standard crooked double agents supporting roles, it just smacks of an easy pay cheque to all involved, some trying to big up their careers while the good stuff stalls and others just grateful for the work still coming their way in the autumn of their careers. Other than that, it's really hard to figure out what anyone involved was hoping to achieve from it. **

My recommendation to you if you watch this film is to skip to all the fight scenes, avoid the last 10mins and keep your TV muted.

column9:
Going in, I wanted to like Haywire and I gave it the benefit of the doubt, but the movie was just average with only a couple positives that couldn't overcome the substantial misses. Gina Carano plays an international spy who is betrayed by her own people and fights to clear her name and save her life.

Gina Carano was good in the lead role. Although she seemed to be reading lines in many scenes, she was captivating as the protagonist. Her action scenes were fun and energetic, and she was effective playing a strong and emotionless spy fighting in a man's world. She has a captivating presence, but she does need some acting lessons.

The supporting actors were very disappointing, as most just mailed in flat performances to collect a check. From Ewan McGregor to Antonio Banderas to Channing Tatum, their acting was flat and disengaged. The actors seemed unsettled in supporting roles to a Hollywood newcomer and enduring some less than flattering scenes for them.

In addition, I struggled with the directing. The movie lacked a good pace, dragging in several places. For example,a scene of the main character walking down a sidewalk seemed to last forever and become almost comical. And, several dramatic and climatic scenes actually drew laughter from the audience, as they seemed almost cartoonish.

Haywire is at best a Netflix rental when you can't find anything else of value to watch. Gina Carano, despite her flaws, is the only positive in an otherwise poorly acted and poorly directed action film.

column9:
This is definitely one of the lesser Soderbergh movies that I have seen. But as it turns out; even a lesser Soderbergh is still a perfectly watchable movie.

There were quite a few issues I was having with this movie, while watching it. It picks an original enough spy genre approach, that just isn't a very exciting one however. Seems that it wanted to go for realism but yet the movie is being filmed as a typical action-flick, even while this is definitely not a spectacular or action-filled movie.

But also the story itself is being told in such a messy way that it becomes just too hard to follow. It makes you loose interest in it, pretty early on already. It doesn't help that the movie feels like it isn't going anywhere with its story. It doesn't lay things out clearly for you and you constantly need to pay attention. Nothing wrong with that of course but it just doesn't work out too well for the movie. simply because it's never getting interesting enough. I just couldn't care less about anything that was happening in it, or for any of its characters.

And really, Gina Carano, who plays the lead role, was absolutely horrendous. She just can't act, which totally took me out of the movie. Watching her act with greats such as Michael Douglas, Ewan McGregor, Michael Fassbender and Antonio Banderas doesn't ever look right. Watching her doing spy stuff doesn't ever look right or convincing. And even watching her fight doesn't look right. It sounds strange, since she is a professional fighter and all but seeing her doing wrestling moves, in a spy movie, just doesn't look right at all and came across as quite ridicules, to me.

Nothing about the movie really impressed me but that doesn't mean it's a bad movie as well. It's still a maintaining enough, little spy thriller, that however in the end is extremely forgettable.

6/10

column9:
After watching Deadpool I remembered that I didn't watch this movie, Gina Carano action vehicle from 2011. Now that I have done that I have some questions.

First one - how did this got made in the first place? I find it insane that Soderbergh cast Gina Carano as a goddamn lead in this and then cast all star acting crew around her. I mean, supporting actors here are Tatum, Fassbender, Ewan McGregor, Banderas, Michael Douglas, etc.

Don't get me wrong, stunt casting is sometimes interesting and I generally like Carano in Deadpool but she is so flatfaced and not good in this. Yeah, fights are cool, but you don't get that star cast just to support someone who is a noob actor like her.

It's confusing and kinda boring movie, which is even more perplexing given the great supporting cast. Story is not that good as well and photography is somewhat average with completely uninteresting shots and frames.

Weird-but-not-that-bad movie this Haywire is. Can't recommend it though, except if you want to see how odd it is.

column3: Boring film, with good cast to throw everyone off
column7:
1 out of 5 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
This film, on its own, would have received a subaverage rating for the bad acting, the boring plot and the pointless action. However, done by Soderbergh and having Ewan McGregor, Antonio Banderas, Michael Fassbender and Michael Douglas in the cast... I rate it even lower for the pure impudence of using a few good actors in order to sell a bad film.

The story is simple: betrayed super duper agent seeks the people that set her up. It has been done to death, but each time there was something added to make it interesting: exotic locations, good actors, flamboyant action scenes. Instead, this had a bleak, fractured feel that left the viewer confused and not because the plot was terribly convoluted, but because it was malexplained. Gina Carano is no actress and it shows. The music was something stolen from Ocean's Eleven.

Bottom line: Soderbergh wanted to make a movie and show his craftsmanship in a genre that is making a comeback now, after everybody has forgotten most of the experiments in stupidity from three or four decades ago in the same genre. He called a few friends and made them play small roles so that he could also sell the movie, no matter how bad it was. In the end, he can cry that no one understands art while he counts the cash he makes from duped viewers like you and me. Shame on you, Soderbergh!

1 out of 5 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

column9:
I was really looking forward to a 'Bourne' type of movie with a lead female actress. Although this movie didn't receive a very high voting, I still wanted to check it out, because action type movies tend to be very underrated compared to other genres.

So there am I, starting to watch this movie. First scene, a guy walks into a bar, sits down next to a beautiful lady, chit-chats with her for a few minutes, and then they start fighting. So here comes the one big, positive point in this movie, the fighting. You cannot help but realize that the protagonist being a woman, she is bound to have problems in her fights with bigger and heavier men, and this issue is handled perfectly. Not once does it feel too forced, and it's just the kind of kicking butts you might expect from this type of character.

Unhappily, this is where the praise ends.

Every other aspect of this movie, and I mean it, was fairly dreadful. First of all the story. It's just C-grade no imagination standard Hollywood script. It is so foreseeable it is not even funny after a time. But that wouldn't have killed the movie by itself.

This female actor, Gina Carano, as I learned after wieving the movie, is in her first serious role. And there is not really another way to say it: she cannot act. She simply can't. When you see her in her dress talking with other people, it feels wrong. When she is running away from the police, she behaves in an odd girlish (I'm sorry, this is what best describes it in my opinion) way that feels wrong. The problem is, that 85% of the screen time is just her. And she can't handle it. And even other actors like Micheal Douglas, or Evan McGregor cannot save her performance since they are accorded so little room in the movie. At times it's just painful to watch.

And then another thing: the music. I don't know if this was meant to be a joke, but it is so out of place I can hardly put words on it. I guess to closest music to this one would be the ones played in TV commercials. And that's how you feel. When she is being chased: TV commercial. When she fights the bad guys: TV commercial. When she expresses emotions (not very often): TV commercial. It really kills the movie.

I don't usually do this, but I fast-forwarded through the last half hour of the movie. My advice: don't watch it. It's not worth your money, not even your time. The only thing that makes this 2 stars instead of one is the great effort on the fighting scenes.

column9:
Some type of secret operative named Mallory, played by Carano, arrives at a diner. Later another operative, played by Tatum, arrives. A fight breaks out between the two. She escapes in a car kidnapping the owner. For some reason she decides to tell him everything.

Some time in the past she was given a mission in Barcelona to rescue some Chinese guy who was held captive. The mission doesn't go smoothly but succeeds. After that mission, her handler asks her to take on a simple mission in Ireland playing an agent's wife. Once there she notices things aren't quite right. And sure enough, the agent tries to kill her. She also finds the Chinese guy she rescued before dead in a barn.

Mallory now is on her own with law enforcement on her trail. She manages to escape and make it to the US- to the diner. Back in the US she continues to be on the run from her black ops colleagues. Her father is a renowned war history author living in New Mexico. She manages to make it over there where she'll be followed by her enemies.

There is also a politician behind all this pulling the strings. And in the end we find out exactly what is going on. The whole rescue operation of the Chinese was more like a private vendetta by a some corrupt rich guy trying to rid himself of his enemies and Mallory knew too much so she had to be eliminated by the very people she trusted.

Haywire has a good story and great action scenes. Carano is gorgeous and can actually fight. This isn't your typical anorexic Hollywood actress pretending to be an invincible action superheroine. Her voice-acting isn't convincing though. Since they tinkered with her voice in post-production, it's hard to tell if the issue is with Carano or post-production. Regardless, I applaud the decision to cast Carano. In the hands of another director, things could have turned out differently. Usually directors go out of their way to glorify their female leads beating up on 300lb guys. Soderbergh doesn't know how to do that. Not only that, but direction in general is very spotty. It's hard to believe this was directed by Soderbergh. This movie comes across like the work of a foreign first-time director. Another thing that ruins the movie is the ridiculous music. Music has a place in movies, it shouldn't be treated like a lead character though. And in this movie we get to hear constantly some silly caper tune that belonged in one those awful Ocean's 13 movies. Here it's played loudly over exciting events or action scenes.

Haywire had a lot potential, an excellent cast, a strong story, but direction is so poor that it manages to ruin it.

column9: This is a fast forward movie , just fast forward to the fight scenes and skip the rest. Haywire is set up as a start of a new action movie franchise starring Gina Carano (top womens mma athlete)but falls short on many things essential for a good movie . The plot doesn't seem to be one of these essential parts for the producers of this movie (as it should have been) and is merely a ploy to introduce us to the main character and her fight scenes. Other parts of the movie that failed are the dialog and the music , great movie music you notice , average movie score you don't notice but bad ones annoy you as did the score in Haywire. Now the good part, the action scenes and specially the Gina Carano fight scenes are great. I have been disappointed recently with fight scenes that get cut up in flashy shots of no longer then 2 seconds pasted together showing the viewer nothing of the fight. This movie has some good fight scenes showing you everything in long and wide shots, and with Gina Carano we actually get to see some proper BJJ moves including arm bars , guillotine choke and a proper triangle choke (the first in action movie history ?). See it for the fight scenes , skip the rest and hope that if they do make a sequel they spend a little more time on the script.

I usually like Soderberg, but this one is just... lame. This is one of those movies where, if you watched it in a theater, someone near you would be going "Who's that?" and "Why did they do THAT?"... only this time it would be YOU.

This movie has so much "WTF?" in it that it makes a typical Hong Kong action picture make perfect and complete sense by comparison. The fight sequences are probably fairly honest -- she does get her butt kicked as often as she kicks ass, and doesn't win against other martially trained males easily. The lack of swelling after getting clocked in the face a few times is a bit unrealistic, but we'll give them that much...

I give it a "4" for the fight sequences. But that's -really- the only thing that's any good, and only a little bit of those are really inventive in terms of moves.

She must have been hired for her fighting skills and not her acting ability. I doubt I'll be seeing anything with Gina Carano again anytime soon.

column3: One hot super agent and nothing coherent
column7:
1 out of 7 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
Mallory Kane (Gina Carano) is some kind of secretive government agent or super-spy. We are never explained what she does because apparently all that matters is that she is very good at beating up fellow agents and killing bad guys, and vice versa. Everything that she does is complete nonsense. I'm assuming because she's a girl, that's supposed to make it cool rather than stupid.

The beginning is set in upstate New York where after she karate chops Channing Tatum to within an inch of his life, she runs away with Michael Angarano. I have loved his characters in all of his previous movies, but here, he willingly hands her his keys and she abducts him with his car and "explains" what's going on. None of which made any sense but the only clarification he needed was with their names. I don't even know what to say to that.

A third of the way through we settle down for a few moments without action in Ireland (this is after a trip through many different cities for no reason). The action didn't stop so we could get to know characters; the action stopped so we could start getting interested in Mallory. She appears to have been set-up but by who and why is probably never going to get answered. So I think we're only supposed to ogle at how sexy she is as she jumps over buildings and other such escapades.

It's directed by Steven Soderbergh and at least there's credit to that as the shots were beautifully crafted with great lighting and use of colour. There are many great actors but I have no idea why since none of them had anything to do, except dying. Actors do love their death scenes. But "Haywire" failed to give me any reason to watch this.

column3: First a porn star. Now an MMA fighter. Could Soderbergh's next obsession be, like, an actress or something?
column7:
1 out of 7 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
If you've spent any time at all over the last 30 years in video stores, you've probably seen a certain sub-section of the action genre where low-budget filmmakers corral themselves a reasonably attractive female martial artist, or at least someone with enough training to be passed off as such, and decide to make a movie out of her beating guys senseless. Haywire is, nothing more and nothing less, the classiest such motion picture to date. It's got the best cast any such flick has ever dreamed of having. The star is probably the most legitimate and dynamic ass-kicker ever seen in such a project. And under the direction of Steven Soderbergh, Haywire looks a thousand times better than any such film ever has. This basically could pass as another Ocean's movie, just without Clooney, Pitt or 99% of the sense of humor. However, all that talent and skills fails to obscure the fact that this entire production is just a shrine to the physicality of MMA star Gina Carano. Not that I'm complaining, mind you.

Mallory Kane (Gina Carano) is what used to be called a mercenary but is now usually referred to as a "contractor". She works for a private security/paramilitary company run by her ex-boyfriend Kenneth (Ewan McGregor). He talks her into taking a job in Barcelona to rescue a hostage and then talks her into another job in Dublin where the Barcelona hostage turns up dead and Mallory is set up to take the blame for it. She foils that but still winds up on the run trying to figure out who set her up, why and how she can choke him to death with her thighs.

Let's be frank. Whatever impulse it was that drove Soderbergh to make The Girlfriend Experience with porn star Sasha Grey is the same thing that resulted in Haywire getting made with Carano, but things worked out much better this time around. Unlike Grey, Carano can actually do what she's good at on screen without getting an X-rating. That means Soderbergh is able to craft a movie around Carano's athleticism and hand-to-hand combat prowess rather than come up with some cock and bull plot about internet escort subculture and the financial crisis of the late 2000s. This film puts Mallory Kane in peril and then sits back and watches her turn that peril back upon her attackers.

Which means that, for all Soderbergh's ability, what makes or breaks Haywire is Carano and her performance. Her fight scenes are excellent. Gifted with a woman who can take a hell of a punch and dish one out, the movie dispenses with camera movement and quick cuts. Carano and her male co-stars are allowed to battle in clear, linear fashion and the result is scenes where it looks like people are actually getting hurt. This isn't choreographed ballet. It's trained killers trying to do each other in. Carano has a fluidity of movement that's not at all Jackie Chan-ish. You never look at her and think she's dancing. She's fighting.

As for her acting? Wellshe doesn't embarrass herself but that may only be because Carano is asked to do so very little in Haywire. She reads her lines competently but any emoting is kept at the most simple levels, by design or accident, and she more or less pulls off what she's asked to do. If Carano looks bad, it's only in comparison to the high quality cast surrounding her. But if you're in a line up with Michael Douglas, Ewan McGregor, Antonio Banderas and Bill Paxton, it's not going to be hard for viewers to spot the non-actor in the group.

There's nothing exceptional here with the story, dialog or filmmaking, save for one scene involving a seemingly suicidal deer. Haywire only looks great in comparison to the rest of its sub-genre. Compared to similar movies with similar casts and similar creators, there's little here that stands out. Soderbergh didn't go into this with any other thought in his head except "Man, I really dig that Gina Carano". If you watch this film, you'll probably dig her too but I'll be surprised if this isn't the high point by far of any career Carano has in cinema. We can only hope the pattern continues and the next time Soderbergh becomes infatuated with some non-actress, that project will be better than Haywire as much as Haywire is better than The Girlfriend Experience.

column3: Art-house meets Bourne: a recipe for dissatisfaction
column7:
1 out of 8 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
Soderbergh in the director's chair. The cast looked promising with McGregor, Douglas, Tatum, Banderas and Fassbender on the bill. Carano is a credible martial artist and so all that was required was a decent script. Aargh! The script! Someone obviously forgot about the script.

This film has a touch of the 'Oceans' about it - unsurprising, given the director. However, what we end up with is neither thought-provoking thriller nor adrenalin-pumping action fodder, but a rather unsatisfying mishmash of the two genres.

Rule number one: make your audience feel something about the lead character. Engendering a feeling of indifference means that you've failed. This tale is definitely back-story lite. If I don't have enough of a back-story to work with then there is little chance of developing some sort of rapport with any of the protagonists.

Stick Carano in something like a Witchblade remake and I'll watch it. Otherwise, get a decent action movie director in the chair for her next cinematic excursion.

column3: Another muddled mess from Steven Soderbergh
column7:
1 out of 8 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9: Steven Soderbergh, Hollywood's most overrated living director, once again demonstrates his talents are closer to Ed Wood than Sergio Leone, with "Haywire". How else can one explain how mixed-martial arts expert Gina Carano can appear less capable than Angelina Jolie in "Salt," "Wanted" or either of the Lara Croft films. However, like Jolie, Carano is another striking beauty and has enough acting chops to generate interests in spite of Soderbergh's ineptitude. This is no small achievement, given the inability of veterans Oscar winner Michael Douglas, multiple Golden Globe nominees Antonio Banderas and Bill Paxton to register any impact at all. Soderbergh's annoying style of using minimal, frequently unintelligible dialog, medium shots which fail to capture acting nuances and little or no establishing narrative certainly don't help. Even the guns look phony in "Haywire". As much as I normally hate voice-overs, I certainly would have welcomed Carano's, not only because her voice is sexy, but because I would have actually understood what the heck was going on before I lost interest. Maybe next time, Carano will be fortunate enough to work with Phil Noyce ("Salt") or Doug Liman (The Bourne Series) or someone who actually understands how to direct engaging action films. I give "Haywire" a 5, solely for showcasing Carano.

Haywire comes off as an excuse to stage a few well choreographed fight scenes. Unfortunately they get lost in the middle of a lumbering uninventive emotionally dead story with with stick figure characters, the 'stickiest' of which is the lead.

As good a fighter as Gina Carano is, that's how inept she is as an actress. She has the delivery of someone reading of a teleprompter and the emotional capability of the T1000.

If I didn't know that this is a Steven Soderberg film, I might well have guessed that it was the product of Luc Besson. It doesn't work on any level whatsoever. Enough said.

column3: Just a really badly directed film
column7:
1 out of 9 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

column9:
Beside the rating of 1 out of 10 it has in brackets (awful). This is just the word to describe this film, it is truly awful.

I really can't believe what I am reading in some reviews praising this film because I must say this film was one of the poorest excuses for a spy thriller I have ever had to endure, can you believe I picked this over Ghost Protocol in the DVD store? I haven't read one review on Tom Cruise's latest film but I know it wil be better than this.

The only good thing about this film was the well-choreographed fight scenes that are not enough to make a film watchable. I don't think I seen any blood drawn though so maybe I'm being over-the-top in saying they were good, they did not redemm this film in any way.

Wooden acting by the female lead, long drawn out sequences in the film were nothing much is happening, a very loose story-line that I didn't really care much about. I would rate this film as 1 star for everything apart from the fight scenes, they get a 3. A decent cast that somehow got fooled into making this terrible film, I feel sorry for them. I wonder just how awkward it must have been the first time they sat down to watch the edited cut?

This film should have went straight to DVD and even at that should have come with a warning as to just how bad a film this is. I blame the director entirely.

I believe there is a lot of false PR being put out online praising this film because I have never felt the need to write a review on a film until I watched this. I can think of two really badly acted/directed films I've previously seen but they turned out to be the film director's student films dressed up as a feature film, Haywire was just as bad.

column9:
Another case of "awesome, bad-ass trailer, crappy movie" I'm afraid.

As in, the one scene that's shown in the trailer that I saw before watching this movie ended up being the very best scene in the entire film (i.e. the part where Gina and Fassbender beat the snot out of each other in their hotel room).

Turns out it's very much downhill from that point forward.

First of all, the acting. Pretty awful. She's better than what you'd expect from an MMA fighter, and much prettier, but it's painfully obvious that the rest of the cast is trying to cover her lack of skill as best they can...and on a sidenote, WOW, I haven't seen that many cameos in a while. Too bad they didn't save the movie in the slightest.

The plot is hard to follow, and what parts you do manage to latch on to are boring as hell.

The dialogue is flat, monotonous, unoriginal...just painful. Rehashed spy-movie one-liners every now and then.

Worst of all? The damned music. Before watching the movie, I had no clue the director was the same guy that made Ocean's Eleven. And yet I definitely caught an Ocean's-Eleven-vibe while listening to the music that plays in almost every chase-scene. They just re-used that theme to DEATH in the worst possible moments, ruining most of the supposed action scenes and only adding to the boredom and disbelief.

I expected a dumb yet entirely FUN movie, where a hot chick beats the tar out of a bunch of guys and drives away into the sunset.

Instead I got the bastard child of Ocean's Eleven and a really, really stale spy flick.

column3: The last line sums the film up....
column7:
1 out of 11 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink
column9:
Mallory Kane is hired out by her handler to various global entities to perform jobs which governments can't authorise and heads of state would rather not know about.

When she finishes one mission, she is immediately dispatched on another mission to Dublin.

When the operation goes awry and Mallory finds she has been double crossed, she needs to use all of her skills, tricks and abilities to escape.

An international manhunt is put in order, but she needs to make it back to the United States, to protect her family, and exact revenge on those that have betrayed her.

The thin is with Soderbergh movies is that he can always recruit a very impressive cast. Ironically, this could be one of the best casts he has ever assembled, for easily his worst movie.

The story and narrative are so stodgy and convoluted, that at times you comment on peoples hair and how much they have grown, which is always a bad sign for a movie.

And despite the lead (who is very good) being a MMA expert, the action scenes and especially the fight scenes, seem way over choreographed and are just too slick. People fall in the right way, and despite the supposed brutality, it all seems very painless.

It's always good to see Douglas on screen, even when he is spouting inane banter like this, but he has very little screen time.

Fassbender is is insanely underused, and the rest of the cast just seem not to be bothered at all.

It's a shame because I was really looking forward to this, but it's nothing new, and it gets very boring, very quickly.

My advice? if you do see this movie, every time Banderas appears, close your eyes, and you instantly have Puss In Boots.

A tragic mess
